<!-- 
Instead of just saying:

“Department X has more FTE than Department Y,”

we can say:

“Departments cluster into distinct roles in our teaching ecosystem. Some provide high-volume, lower-intensity foundational instruction (e.g., English, Psychology). Others offer lower-volume but high-intensity, small-cohort advanced instruction (e.g., Philosophy, Classics). Both are structurally vital but have different workload dynamics.” 

| Type                       | Characteristics                                         |
| -------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Mass Intro Service**     | High enrolments, low FTE per student, mostly 1000-level |
| **Mid-Level Workhorses**   | Balanced FTE and enrolments across levels               |
| **Upper-Year Specialists** | Low enrolments, high per-instructor intensity           |
| **High-Variance Hybrid**   | Swings year to year, mixed levels                       |
| **Low-Load Peripheral**    | Small total teaching footprint                          |


You can absolutely — and meaningfully — look at FTE + Enrolments together to:

Identify structurally different types of labour

Avoid flattening everything into “who does the most”

Build a fairer and more strategic model of workload, role, and sustainability

-->
